Support to Climate Resilient Investment Pathways in the Pacific (KSTA REG 54068) 
TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
 
1.  A firm and a team of international and national consultants will be engaged to assist in 
technical  assistance  (TA)  implementation.  The  TA  will  require  about  70  person-months  of 
international and 50 person-months of national consultant inputs. Listed below are the individual 
consultants to comprise the team which will assist in TA implementation, and the firm to conduct 
the planned multi-hazard assessment in a selected DMC (estimated at 107 person months). 
A climate change economist and other international experts in the field of natural management 
and a geographic information system specialist may also be required (estimated at 13 person 
months).  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  will  engage  all  consultants  and  carry  out 
procurement following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its 
associated project administration instructions and/or staff instructions. 
 
A.  International Consultants 
 
2.  Senior Climate Change Scientist (7 person-months, intermittent). The scope of work is 
to provide technical inputs and guidance to enable ADB investments in the Pacific to contribute 
to systemic resilient low-carbon adaptation pathways in accordance with ADB’s Strategy 20301 
and the Pacific Approach, 2021–2025, which will be finalized in 2021. The consultant will have a 
doctoral degree in a field related to climate change, will have at least 15 years of experience 
working in climate change adaptation related analysis and will have a current affiliation with an 
academic institution. The consultant will be responsible for the following tasks:  
(i)         Support PARD’s Climate Change and DRM team in developing sector-specific 
good  practice  guidance  based  on  insights  gained  from  consultations  with 
international experts, ADB operations departments, DMCs and the latest academic 
literature.  
(ii)  Contribute to the expanded access to data on climate change and disaster risks 
with a specific focus on data relating to SLR, extreme rainfall and changes to 
drought patterns 
(iii)  Contribute to incorporating climate change and DRM considerations into country 
partnership strategies, country programming, and project design.  
(iv)  Contribute to the development of adaptation pathways that enable governments of 
the small island developing states (SIDS) to approach development planning under 
climate change uncertainty and that help decision-makers to sequence measures 
for flexible implementation with limited desirable and maladaptive consequences.  
(v)  Conduct  preliminary  scoping  and  assessment  of  climate  risks  and  project 
vulnerabilities and the design of fit-for-purpose climate risk assessments. This 
includes state-of-the-art reviews of emerging engineering design and decision-
making protocols that reflect the impacts of climate change. 
(vi)  Strengthen the knowledge, skills, and practices of government agencies and ADB 
staff by participating in knowledge events facilitated under the Knowledge and 
Support Technical Assistance Support to Climate Change Resilient Investment 
Pathways in the Pacific.    
(vii)  Any other relevant tasks. 
 
3.  Climate Change and Disaster Risk Management Specialist (2 positions, each for 10 
person-months).  Each  consultant  will  have  at  least  a  master’s  degree  in  economics, 
environmental science, or a related field, and 10 years of experience related to climate change,

and disaster risk management (DRM). Knowledge of ADB and experience in the Pacific are highly 
desirable. Each consultant will be responsible for the following tasks: 
(i)  Conduct an analysis of the key barriers to long-term adaptation in at least two 
DMCs—identifying the full range of economic, political, and governance barriers in 
its Pacific DMCs, as well as benefits and opportunities that adaptation would bring 
to Pacific DMCs.  
(ii)  Contribute to the expanded access to data on climate change and disaster risks 
based on in country consultations, collection of primary data and desk-based 
analysis.  
(iii)  Provide expertise to incorporate climate change and DRM considerations into 
country partnership strategies, country programming, and project design.  
(iv)  Contribute to the development of adaptation pathways that enable governments of 
the SIDS to approach development planning under climate change uncertainty and 
that help decision-makers to sequence measures for flexible implementation with 
limited desirable and maladaptive consequences. 
(v)  Identify opportunities for investment with significant climate change adaptation 
and/or  DRM  benefits  and  climate  and  disaster-proofing  options,  as  well  as 
associated co-benefits, in accordance with national development plans (including 
sector plans, intended nationally determined contributions, National Adaptation 
Plans, and National Action Plans for Disaster Risk Management). 
(vi)  Provide expertise to support ADB to continue its efforts to access external climate 
finance from bi-lateral and multi-lateral sources including developing co-financing 
proposals for the Green Climate Fund, Global Environmental Facility and other co-
financing resources.   
(vii)  Conduct  preliminary  scoping  and  assessment  of  climate  risks  and  project 
vulnerabilities and the design of fit-for-purpose climate risk assessments. This 
includes state-of-the-art reviews of emerging engineering design and decision-
making protocols that reflect the impacts of climate change. 
(viii)  Conduct economic analyses of projects and estimate the incremental costs of 
adaptation 
(ix)  Strengthen the knowledge, skills, and practices of government agencies and ADB 
staff by participating in knowledge events facilitated under the Knowledge and 
Support Technical Assistance Support to Climate Change Resilient Investment 
Pathways in the Pacific.  
(x)  Prepare reports as required. 
(xi)  Any other relevant tasks. 
 
B.  National Consultants 
 
4.  Climate  Change  Specialist  (25  person-months).  The  consultant  will  have  at  least 
10 years of experience working in climate change adaptation related project implementation and 
coordination and will hold both undergraduate and master’s degrees in a related field.  
(i)  Coordinate with ADB project teams, consultants and government counterparts in 
implementing the plan of activities. 
(ii)  Attend and participate, as required by the project officer, in all project meetings 
including inception workshops, planning sessions and missions. 
(iii)  Coordinate  with  the  PARD  sector  divisions  to  plan  climate  risk  assessment 
support,  including  contributions  to  developing  Terms  of  Reference  providing 
consultant input to conduct climate risk assessments, and coordinating quality 
assurance and peer review of climate risk assessments. ‘

(iv)  Support the lead consultants conducting the analysis of the key barriers to long-
term adaptation in at least two DMCs—identifying the full range of economic, 
political, and governance barriers in its Pacific DMCs. 
(v)  Contribute to the expanded access to data on climate change and disaster risks 
by supporting coordination with regional partners, data capture and engagement 
with relevant platforms.  
(vi)  Support  PARD’s  work  on  developing  adaptation  pathways  that  enable 
Governments  of  the  SIDS  to  approach  development  planning  under  climate 
change uncertainty and that help decision-makers to sequence measures for 
flexible implementation with limited desirable and maladaptive consequences. 
(vii)  Support ADB to continue its efforts to access external climate finance from bi-
lateral and multi-lateral sources including developing co-financing proposals.  
(viii)  Together  with  the  project  officer,  define  baselines,  targets  and  timelines  for 
implementation; and implement progress monitoring and evaluation. 
(ix)  Review  PARD  experience  on  climate  change  and  the  climate  change 
implementation  plan  and  provide  recommendations  for  updating  the  climate 
change implementation plan, as well as for communication and dissemination of 
lessons. 
(x)  Prepare and submit reports. 
(xi)  Any other relevant tasks. 
 
5.  Project Coordinator (25 person-months). The consultant will have at least 10 years of 
experience in project administration, and a bachelor’s degree in a related field. Experience with 
ADB is highly desirable. The consultant will be responsible for the following tasks: 
(i)  Support the project officer in coordinating implementation of the TA. 
(ii)  Support coordination and scheduling of inputs by consultants. 
(iii)  Develop  project  implementation  schedules  and  apply  adaptive  management 
approaches to ensure smooth delivery of the TA outputs. 
(iv)  Support the recruitment of consultants. 
(v)  Support financial administration of the TA. 
(vi)  Coordinate and organize workshops and meetings. 
(vii)  Create and maintain a database for climate risk assessments and other climate 
information. 
(viii)  Support the preparation of reports, publications, and knowledge products. 
(ix)  Undertake any other tasks needed to ensure the smooth implementation of the TA. 
 
C.  Firm 
 
6.  Multi-Hazard Risk Assessment (international experts, 30 person-months). The draft 
Pacific Approach, 2021–2025 is placing the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) recovery and 
building resilience at the center of ADB’s strategy for engagement in the Pacific for the next 5 
years. To effectively prioritize climate change adaptation components of that strategy and to build 
adaptation pathways for specific population centers, detailed assessments of hazards, exposure 
and risk under climate change considerations are required. This assignment will aim to provide 
the necessary detailed information for Government and ADB for at least one population center in 
one of the SIDS.2 This assignment aims to provide the necessary detailed hazard information 
(covering pluvial inundation, sea level rise including inundation associated king tides and storm

surges, tropical cyclones, drought and seismic events as applicable to the particular setting), 
exposure and vulnerability to generate an in-depth understanding of the increased risk that 
climate change will create for the current and future assets, population and socio-economic 
context.  
 
Scope of Work 
 
7.  The hazard, exposure and vulnerability assessment will comprise the following tasks:  
(i)  A probabilistic hazard assessment of inundation from pluvial flooding, storm surge, 
extreme  sea  levels,  cyclones,  and  drought  under  current  and  future  climate 
conditions including selected sea level rise scenarios. 
(ii)  An  assessment  of  seismic  hazards  as  applicable  to  the  situation  (e.g., 
earthquakes, volcanoes, and tsunamis. 
(iii)  An exposure dataset and assessment of population, buildings, road, power, water 
and communications infrastructure will be developed to estimate the exposure to 
each of the hazards under current and future climate change scenarios. 
(iv)  Physical vulnerability curves for each building types, roads, power, water, and 
communications infrastructure.  
(v)  Development  of  social  vulnerability  indicators  to  estimate  the  impact  on 
household’s livelihood and poverty index. 
(vi)  Conduct a probabilistic risk assessment for each of the hazards. 
(vii)  Develop state-of-the-art communication products for conveying the significance of 
the findings to stakeholders for planning future investments.  
 
8.  Detailed Terms of Reference will be developed based on the particular DMC and urban 
center selected.
